Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with pilot certification, recent experience requirements, and privileges and limitations associated with the private pilot certificate.
Regulatory requirements for private pilot certification, ratings, privileges, and limitations.
Medical certificates: class, expiration dates, privileges, temporary disqualifications, and limitations.
Recency of experience requirements and effects of not meeting those requirements.
Privileges and limitations of the private pilot certificate.
Maintaining medical fitness and compliance with applicable regulations.
Temporary medical conditions and their effect on the ability to operate an airplane legally and safely.
Locate and describe private pilot eligibility, aeronautical knowledge, proficiency, privileges, limitations, and recency of experience requirements.

To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with airworthiness requirements, including airplane certificates, required inspections, and documentation.
Required airplane certificates and documents (e.g., airworthiness certificate, registration certificate, operating limitations, weight and balance data).
Airplane maintenance and inspection requirements (e.g., annual, 100-hour, Airworthiness Directives (ADs), preventive maintenance).
Pilot-performed preventive maintenance.
Equipment requirements for day and night VFR flight.
Inoperative instruments or equipment and determining if they constitute a hazard to safe flight.
Minimum equipment list (MEL) and operations with inoperative equipment.
Determine the airplane is airworthy by locating and explaining the required airplane certificates, documents, and inspection requirements.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with obtaining, understanding, and applying weather information for a flight under VFR.
Sources of weather data (e.g., National Weather Service, Flight Service) for flight planning purposes.
Weather products and their uses (e.g., METAR, TAF, FA, winds aloft, weather charts, radar reports, PIREPs, SIGMETs, AIRMETs).
Meteorology to include:
Characteristics of air masses and fronts.
Sources and effects of weather hazards on aviation (e.g., thunderstorms, turbulence, icing, fog).
Relationship between weather and airplane performance.
Making a competent go/no-go decision based on available weather information.
Recognizing weather hazards during flight planning and making a competent decision to alter the planned route or cancel the flight.
Use available aviation weather resources to obtain an adequate weather briefing for the route of flight.
Correlate weather information to make a competent go/no-go decision.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with planning a VFR cross-country flight.
Route planning, including consideration of alternate airports and suitable checkpoints.
Altitude selection accounting for terrain, obstacles, glide distance, and emergency considerations.
Obtaining and interpreting applicable NOTAM information.
Plotting a course with wind correction and computing time, speed, distance, and fuel requirements.
Completing a navigation log and filing a VFR flight plan.
Fuel planning for normal and emergency situations.
Weather unsuitable for VFR flight.
Terrain and obstacle hazards during the planned route of flight.
Prepare, present, and explain a cross-country flight plan based on a scenario provided by the evaluator, including a completed navigation log and VFR flight plan.
Recalculate fuel reserves based on a scenario provided by the evaluator.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with the National Airspace System operating under VFR as a private pilot.
Types of airspace and associated requirements (e.g., Class A, B, C, D, E, G, special use airspace).
Basic VFR weather minimums and operating requirements for each class of airspace.
Special use airspace (e.g., MOA, restricted areas) and operating limitations.
Inadvertent entry into controlled airspace or special use airspace without proper clearance or authorization.
Locate and identify airspace classes and special use airspace on a sectional chart and explain the operational requirements.

To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with operating an airplane safely within the parameters of its performance capabilities and limitations.
Elements and use of performance charts, tables, and data from the POH/AFM.
Effects of exceeding airplane limitations (e.g., weight, balance, airspeed).
Effects of atmospheric conditions (e.g., density altitude, wind, temperature) on performance.
Weight and balance computations and associated impacts on performance.
Exceeding airplane performance limitations during flight.
Improper weight and balance planning and its effect on controllability.
Compute airplane performance and weight and balance for a given scenario using available charts and data.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with the safe operation of systems on the airplane provided for the practical test.
Airplane systems (e.g., powerplant, fuel, oil, electrical, hydraulic, avionics, environmental, landing gear, flight controls, anti-ice/deice).
Indications of system malfunctions and appropriate pilot responses.
Failure to detect system malfunctions or failures prior to or during flight.
Improper management of system failures during flight.
Explain the operation and function of the airplane’s systems and associated instrumentation.

To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with personal health, flight physiology, aeromedical factors, and aeronautical decision-making as it relates to safety of flight.
Aeromedical factors and their effects on pilot performance (e.g., hypoxia, carbon monoxide poisoning, fatigue, dehydration, spatial disorientation).
Use of alcohol, over-the-counter medications, prescription medications, and illegal drugs and their effects on pilot performance.
Aeronautical Decision-Making (ADM) and its application to flight planning and operations.
Flying while impaired by illness, medication, alcohol, fatigue, or emotional distress.
Failure to recognize personal limitations and make a timely decision to delay or discontinue a flight.
Apply principles of ADM to a given scenario and associate personal health and aeromedical factors with safety of flight.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with preparing for safe flight.
Pilot self-assessment for flight (e.g., IMSAFE checklist).
Airplane preflight inspection procedures and requirements per the POH/AFM.
Weather conditions unsuitable for the planned flight.
Improper or insufficient fuel planning for the intended flight.
Airplane condition or equipment deficiencies that would affect safety of flight.
Inspect the airplane with reference to an appropriate checklist.
Verify the airplane is in a condition for safe flight.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with cockpit management.
Cockpit management procedures (e.g., organizing charts, securing loose items, adjusting seats and belts).
Passenger briefing requirements (e.g., seatbelts, exits, sterile cockpit).
Distraction from unsecured items, poor cockpit organization, or ineffective passenger management.
Ensure all loose items in the cockpit are secured.
Brief passengers on the use of safety belts, shoulder harnesses, doors, and emergency exits.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with a safe engine start.
Engine starting procedures, including cold and hot starts, as recommended by the POH/AFM.
Starting under various atmospheric conditions (e.g., cold weather, hot weather).
Propeller safety and avoiding hazards to people or property during engine start.
Engine fire or failure during start.
Position the airplane to minimize hazards to people and property during engine start.
Complete the appropriate checklist for engine starting.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with safe taxi operations.
Airport taxi procedures, including runway incursion avoidance and the use of taxi diagrams.
Effects of wind and taxi speed on controllability.
Collision hazards with obstacles, other aircraft, or personnel during taxi.
Taxiing in adverse weather conditions (e.g., strong winds, low visibility).
Demonstrate proper taxi procedures and adhere to ATC instructions or local procedures.
Maintain positive control of the airplane during taxi and position controls appropriately for wind conditions.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with the before takeoff check.
Purpose and procedures for the before takeoff check per the POH/AFM (e.g., run-up, system checks).
Division of attention between inside and outside the cockpit during the check.
Failure to detect system malfunctions or anomalies prior to takeoff.
Distraction or interruption during the before takeoff check.
Perform the before takeoff checklist and confirm the airplane is in a safe condition for flight.
Review takeoff performance, departure procedures, and emergency contingencies.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Task: A. Communications, Light Signals, and Runway Lighting Systems
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with radio communications, light signals, and runway lighting systems.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Task: A. Communications, Light Signals, and Runway Lighting Systems
Description: Radio communication procedures and phraseology at controlled and uncontrolled airports.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Task: A. Communications, Light Signals, and Runway Lighting Systems
Description: Airport signage, markings, and lighting (e.g., runway, taxiway, threshold).

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Task: A. Communications, Light Signals, and Runway Lighting Systems
Description: ATC light gun signals and their meanings.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Task: A. Communications, Light Signals, and Runway Lighting Systems
Description: Misunderstanding or failure to comply with ATC instructions or light signals.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Task: A. Communications, Light Signals, and Runway Lighting Systems
Description: Radio failure and its impact on airport operations.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Task: A. Communications, Light Signals, and Runway Lighting Systems
Description: Use proper radio communication procedures or light signals to depart from or arrive at an airport.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Task: A. Communications, Light Signals, and Runway Lighting Systems
Description: Interpret airport signage, markings, and lighting during taxi, takeoff, and landing.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with traffic patterns.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Description: Airport traffic pattern procedures, altitudes, and entry/exit methods.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Description: Right-of-way rules and collision avoidance during traffic pattern operations.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Description: Collision hazards with other aircraft in the traffic pattern.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Description: Wake turbulence avoidance during traffic pattern operations.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Description: Comply with proper traffic pattern procedures at controlled and uncontrolled airports.

Area of Operation: III. Airport and Seaplane Base Operations
Description: Maintain proper spacing from other aircraft in the traffic pattern.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with a normal takeoff, climb operations, and collision avoidance.
Normal takeoff and climb procedures per the POH/AFM.
Effects of aircraft configuration (e.g., flaps) and atmospheric conditions on takeoff and climb performance.
Runway conditions affecting takeoff performance (e.g., wet, contaminated, short).
Collision hazards with obstacles, terrain, or other aircraft during takeoff and climb.
Wake turbulence avoidance during takeoff.
Low altitude maneuvering and collision avoidance during climb.
Complete the appropriate checklist.
Make radio calls as appropriate.
Verify and position flight controls appropriately for wind conditions and runway alignment.
Align the airplane on the runway centerline and apply takeoff power smoothly.
Rotate and lift off at the recommended airspeed and climb at an appropriate pitch attitude.
Establish and maintain Vy or the appropriate climb speed ±10 knots.
Maintain directional control and proper wind-drift correction throughout the takeoff and climb.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with a normal approach and landing.
Normal approach and landing procedures per the POH/AFM.
Effects of aircraft configuration (e.g., flaps), wind, and atmospheric conditions on landing performance.
Unstabilized approach and failure to execute a go-around when appropriate.
Runway conditions affecting landing performance (e.g., wet, contaminated, short).
Collision hazards with obstacles, terrain, or other aircraft during approach and landing.
Wake turbulence during approach and landing.
Complete the appropriate checklist.
Make radio calls as appropriate.
Establish the recommended approach and landing configuration and airspeed, ±10 knots.
Maintain a stabilized approach and recommended airspeed, or in its absence, not more than 1.3 Vso, ±10 knots, to the flare.
Touch down smoothly at an appropriate airspeed within 400 feet beyond a specified point, with no drift, and aligned with the runway centerline.
Maintain crosswind correction and directional control throughout the approach and landing.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with a soft-field takeoff and climb.
Soft-field takeoff and climb procedures per the POH/AFM.
Effects of soft or uneven surfaces on takeoff performance.
Surface conditions affecting takeoff performance (e.g., wet grass, mud).
Collision hazards with obstacles or terrain during takeoff and climb from a soft field.
Premature liftoff or settling back onto the surface after liftoff.
Complete the appropriate checklist.
Make radio calls as appropriate.
Verify and position flight controls appropriately for wind conditions and surface.
Taxi onto the takeoff surface at a speed consistent with safety and apply takeoff power smoothly while maintaining directional control.
Lift off at the lowest possible airspeed and remain in ground effect until accelerating to an appropriate climb speed.
Climb at an appropriate speed (e.g., Vx or Vy) ±10 knots until obstacles are cleared, then transition to a normal climb.
Maintain directional control and proper wind-drift correction throughout the takeoff and climb.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with a soft-field approach and landing.
Soft-field approach and landing procedures per the POH/AFM.
Effects of soft or uneven surfaces on landing performance.
Unstabilized approach and failure to execute a go-around when appropriate.
Surface conditions affecting landing performance (e.g., wet grass, mud).
Collision hazards with obstacles or terrain during approach and landing on a soft field.
Complete the appropriate checklist.
Make radio calls as appropriate.
Establish the recommended approach and landing configuration and airspeed, ±10 knots.
Maintain a stabilized approach and recommended airspeed, or in its absence, not more than 1.3 Vso, ±10 knots, to the flare.
Touch down softly at minimum controllable airspeed with no drift, and aligned with the runway centerline.
Maintain crosswind correction and directional control throughout the approach and landing, keeping weight off the nosewheel.

Task: E. Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with a short-field takeoff and maximum performance climb.

Task: E. Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
Description: Short-field takeoff and maximum performance climb procedures per the POH/AFM.

Task: E. Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
Description: Effects of runway length, surface, and obstacles on takeoff and climb performance.

Task: E. Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
Description: Runway conditions affecting takeoff performance (e.g., wet, contaminated).

Task: E. Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
Description: Collision hazards with obstacles or terrain during takeoff and climb from a short field.

Task: E. Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
Description: Failure to achieve maximum performance during climb.

Task: E. Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
Description: Complete the appropriate checklist.

Task: E. Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
Description: Make radio calls as appropriate.

Task: E. Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
Description: Verify and position flight controls appropriately for wind conditions and runway alignment.

Task: E. Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
Description: Align the airplane on the runway centerline, utilizing maximum available takeoff area, and apply takeoff power smoothly.

Task: E. Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
Description: Rotate and lift off at the recommended airspeed and climb at Vx ±5 knots until obstacles are cleared, then transition to Vy ±10 knots.

Task: E. Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
Description: Maintain directional control and proper wind-drift correction throughout the takeoff and climb.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with a short-field approach and landing.
Short-field approach and landing procedures per the POH/AFM.
Effects of runway length, surface, and wind on landing performance.
Unstabilized approach and failure to execute a go-around when appropriate.
Runway conditions affecting landing performance (e.g., wet, contaminated).
Collision hazards with obstacles or terrain during approach and landing on a short field.
Complete the appropriate checklist.
Make radio calls as appropriate.
Establish the recommended approach and landing configuration and airspeed, ±10 knots.
Maintain a stabilized approach and recommended airspeed, or in its absence, not more than 1.3 Vso, ±5 knots, to the flare.
Touch down at or within 200 feet beyond a specified point, with no drift, and aligned with the runway centerline.
Apply brakes as necessary to stop in the shortest distance consistent with safety.
Maintain crosswind correction and directional control throughout the approach and landing.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with a go-around/rejected landing.
Go-around/rejected landing procedures per the POH/AFM.
Situations requiring a go-around (e.g., unstabilized approach, runway incursion).
Delayed decision to initiate a go-around.
Collision hazards with obstacles or terrain during a go-around.
Improper application of power or configuration during a go-around.
Make a timely decision to discontinue the approach and initiate a go-around.
Apply takeoff power immediately and transition to a climb pitch attitude with appropriate configuration.
Climb at an appropriate airspeed (e.g., Vy or manufacturer’s recommended speed) ±10 knots.
Maintain directional control and proper wind-drift correction throughout the go-around.
Complete the appropriate checklist and make radio calls as appropriate.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with steep turns.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Purpose and procedures for performing steep turns.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Aerodynamics of steep turns (e.g., load factor, stall speed increase).

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Overbanking tendency and loss of control during steep turns.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Collision hazards during maneuvering flight.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Low altitude maneuvering and stall/spin awareness.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Establish the manufacturer’s recommended airspeed or, if not specified, a safe airspeed not to exceed VA.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Roll into a coordinated 45° bank turn (±5°), maintaining altitude ±100 feet and airspeed ±10 knots.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Reverse the turn to the opposite direction while maintaining altitude and airspeed within tolerances.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Maintain coordination throughout the maneuver (e.g., ball centered).

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with ground reference maneuvers.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Purpose and procedures for rectangular course, S-turns, and turns around a point.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Effects of wind on ground track and maneuvering flight.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Collision hazards with obstacles or other aircraft during ground reference maneuvers.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Low altitude maneuvering and stall/spin awareness.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Improper wind correction leading to drift off the intended ground track.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Select a suitable reference point or course and enter the maneuver at an appropriate altitude (600-1,000 feet AGL) and airspeed ±10 knots.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Apply proper wind-drift correction to maintain a consistent ground track around the selected reference point or course.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Divide attention between airplane control and maintaining the ground track, keeping altitude ±100 feet and bank angle ±10°.

Area of Operation: V. Performance and Ground Reference Maneuvers
Description: Maintain coordination throughout the maneuver (e.g., ball centered).
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with pilotage and dead reckoning.
Pilotage and dead reckoning navigation techniques (e.g., use of charts, checkpoints, time/speed/distance).
Effects of wind on navigation and groundspeed.
Disorientation or getting lost during navigation.
Fuel management during cross-country flight.
Collision hazards with terrain or obstacles during low-altitude navigation.
Navigate by pilotage using preplanned checkpoints and landmarks.
Navigate by dead reckoning using precomputed headings, groundspeeds, and elapsed time, ±10 minutes or 10 miles.
Verify position using ground references and adjust course as necessary.

Task: B. Navigation Systems and Radar Services
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with navigation systems and radar services.

Task: B. Navigation Systems and Radar Services
Description: Use and limitations of navigation systems (e.g., VOR, GPS) and their operating procedures.

Task: B. Navigation Systems and Radar Services
Description: Radar services available to VFR pilots (e.g., flight following, weather radar).

Task: B. Navigation Systems and Radar Services
Description: Overreliance on navigation systems without cross-checking with other methods.

Task: B. Navigation Systems and Radar Services
Description: Failure to recognize navigation system malfunctions or errors.

Task: B. Navigation Systems and Radar Services
Description: Use an installed navigation system (e.g., VOR, GPS) to navigate to a specified point or along a predetermined route.

Task: B. Navigation Systems and Radar Services
Description: Use radar services (e.g., flight following) when available and appropriate during navigation.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with diverting to an alternate airport.
Procedures for diverting to an alternate airport, including course, altitude, and fuel considerations.
Delayed decision to divert, leading to fuel exhaustion or encountering adverse conditions.
Collision hazards with terrain or obstacles during a diversion.
Select an appropriate alternate airport and route based on a scenario provided by the evaluator.
Estimate heading, groundspeed, ETA, and fuel required to reach the alternate airport, ±10 minutes or 10 miles.
Navigate to the alternate airport using available navigation methods.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with lost procedures.
Lost procedures (e.g., 5 Cs: Climb, Circle, Conserve, Communicate, Confess).
Disorientation leading to fuel exhaustion or controlled flight into terrain.
Failure to seek assistance when lost.
Use an appropriate lost procedure to determine position and navigate to a known location or airport.
Communicate with ATC or other available resources to assist in determining position.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with maneuvering during slow flight in various configurations.
Aerodynamics of slow flight (e.g., increased angle of attack, decreased airspeed).
Performance and limitations during slow flight in various configurations.
Inadvertent stall or spin during slow flight.
Collision hazards during low-altitude slow flight.
Establish and maintain an airspeed that results in minimum controllable airspeed or just above stall warning activation, ±10 knots.
Perform coordinated turns, climbs, and descents while maintaining altitude ±100 feet and bank ±10°.
Maintain coordination throughout the maneuver (e.g., ball centered).
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with power-off stalls.
Aerodynamics of power-off stalls (e.g., critical angle of attack, stall progression).
Indications of an impending stall (e.g., buffet, stall warning).
Inadvertent spin during a stall maneuver.
Collision hazards during low-altitude stall practice.
Select an entry altitude that allows recovery above 1,500 feet AGL or the manufacturer’s recommended altitude, whichever is higher.
Establish a power-off descent and induce a stall in a straight-ahead or turning configuration (up to 20° bank).
Recognize the first indication of a stall and promptly recover by reducing angle of attack, applying maximum power, and leveling the wings, maintaining altitude ±100 feet after recovery.
Maintain coordination throughout the maneuver (e.g., ball centered).
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with power-on stalls.
Aerodynamics of power-on stalls (e.g., torque, spiraling slipstream).
Indications of an impending stall during power-on conditions.
Inadvertent spin during a power-on stall maneuver.
Collision hazards during low-altitude stall practice.
Select an entry altitude that allows recovery above 1,500 feet AGL or the manufacturer’s recommended altitude, whichever is higher.
Establish takeoff or departure configuration with power set to no less than 65% available power and induce a stall in a straight-ahead or turning configuration (up to 20° bank).
Recognize the first indication of a stall and promptly recover by reducing angle of attack, applying maximum power, and leveling the wings, maintaining altitude ±100 feet after recovery.
Maintain coordination throughout the maneuver (e.g., ball centered).
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge and risk management associated with spins (spin demonstration is not required).
Aerodynamics of spins (e.g., stalled condition, autorotation).
Situations that could lead to an inadvertent spin (e.g., uncoordinated flight, stall during a turn).
Spin recovery procedures per the POH/AFM.
Situations that could lead to an inadvertent spin and failure to recognize or recover promptly.
Explain spin aerodynamics, recognition, and recovery procedures based on a scenario provided by the evaluator.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with maintaining straight-and-level flight solely by reference to instruments.
Instrument indications for straight-and-level flight (e.g., attitude indicator, altimeter, heading indicator).
Instrument scan and interpretation techniques.
Spatial disorientation and improper instrument cross-check.
Maintain straight-and-level flight using proper instrument cross-check and interpretation, ±200 feet altitude and ±20° heading.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with constant airspeed climbs solely by reference to instruments.
Instrument indications for constant airspeed climbs (e.g., airspeed indicator, attitude indicator, vertical speed indicator).
Spatial disorientation and improper instrument cross-check during climbs.
Transition to a constant airspeed climb from straight-and-level flight, maintaining airspeed ±10 knots, heading ±20°, and altitude ±200 feet at termination.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with constant airspeed descents solely by reference to instruments.
Instrument indications for constant airspeed descents (e.g., airspeed indicator, attitude indicator, vertical speed indicator).
Spatial disorientation and improper instrument cross-check during descents.
Transition to a constant airspeed descent from straight-and-level flight, maintaining airspeed ±10 knots, heading ±20°, and altitude ±200 feet at termination.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with turns to headings solely by reference to instruments.
Instrument indications for turns to headings (e.g., attitude indicator, heading indicator, turn coordinator).
Standard-rate turns and their relationship to heading changes.
Spatial disorientation and improper instrument cross-check during turns.
Perform a standard-rate turn to a specified heading, maintaining altitude ±200 feet, airspeed ±10 knots, and roll out on heading ±10°.

Task: E. Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with recovering from unusual flight attitudes solely by reference to instruments.

Task: E. Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes
Description: Instrument indications of unusual flight attitudes (e.g., nose-high, nose-low, excessive bank).

Task: E. Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes
Description: Recovery procedures for unusual flight attitudes per the POH/AFM.

Task: E. Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes
Description: Spatial disorientation and delayed recovery from unusual attitudes.

Task: E. Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes
Description: Exceeding airplane limitations during recovery attempts.

Task: E. Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes
Description: Recognize an unusual flight attitude and apply appropriate recovery techniques using proper instrument cross-check, returning to straight-and-level flight.

Task: F. Radio Communications, Navigation Systems/Facilities, and Radar Services
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with radio communications, navigation systems/facilities, and radar services under simulated or actual instrument conditions.

Task: F. Radio Communications, Navigation Systems/Facilities, and Radar Services
Description: Radio communication procedures under instrument conditions (e.g., ATC clearance, emergency communications).

Task: F. Radio Communications, Navigation Systems/Facilities, and Radar Services
Description: Use of navigation systems/facilities (e.g., VOR, GPS) for instrument flight.

Task: F. Radio Communications, Navigation Systems/Facilities, and Radar Services
Description: Radar services available under instrument conditions (e.g., vectors, weather avoidance).

Task: F. Radio Communications, Navigation Systems/Facilities, and Radar Services
Description: Miscommunication with ATC or failure to comply with instructions.

Task: F. Radio Communications, Navigation Systems/Facilities, and Radar Services
Description: Overreliance on navigation systems without cross-checking.

Task: F. Radio Communications, Navigation Systems/Facilities, and Radar Services
Description: Use proper radio communication procedures to obtain information or assistance from ATC or other facilities under simulated or actual instrument conditions.

Task: F. Radio Communications, Navigation Systems/Facilities, and Radar Services
Description: Use an installed navigation system/facility to intercept and track a specified course or radial.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with performing an emergency descent.
Situations requiring an emergency descent (e.g., cabin fire, depressurization).
Emergency descent procedures per the POH/AFM.
Delayed initiation of an emergency descent.
Exceeding airplane limitations during an emergency descent.
Recognize the need for an emergency descent and initiate the procedure promptly per the POH/AFM.
Maintain positive load factors and airspeed within limitations during the descent, ±10 knots of recommended speed.
Level off at a specified altitude, ±200 feet.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with an emergency approach and landing.
Situations requiring an emergency approach and landing (e.g., engine failure).
Emergency approach and landing procedures per the POH/AFM.
Delayed decision to execute an emergency landing.
Collision hazards with obstacles or terrain during an emergency approach and landing.
Analyze the situation and select an appropriate landing area within gliding distance.
Establish and maintain the recommended best glide airspeed, ±10 knots, and configuration for the emergency approach.
Maneuver to land in the selected area, considering wind, terrain, and obstacles, and complete the appropriate checklist.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with systems and equipment malfunctions.
Common systems and equipment malfunctions (e.g., electrical failure, vacuum failure, landing gear issues).
Emergency procedures for systems and equipment malfunctions per the POH/AFM.
Failure to recognize and respond to systems or equipment malfunctions.
Improper management of malfunctions leading to loss of control or unsafe flight conditions.
Recognize a system or equipment malfunction and apply appropriate emergency procedures per the POH/AFM based on a scenario provided by the evaluator.
Maintain control of the airplane while managing the malfunction.

Task: D. Emergency Equipment and Survival Gear
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge and risk management associated with emergency equipment and survival gear.

Task: D. Emergency Equipment and Survival Gear
Description: Emergency equipment and survival gear typically carried on board (e.g., fire extinguisher, first aid kit, life vests).

Task: D. Emergency Equipment and Survival Gear
Description: Use and limitations of emergency equipment and survival gear.

Task: D. Emergency Equipment and Survival Gear
Description: Failure to ensure availability or proper use of emergency equipment and survival gear.

Task: D. Emergency Equipment and Survival Gear
Description: Identify and explain the use of emergency equipment and survival gear on board the airplane based on a scenario provided by the evaluator.

Task: A. Maneuvering with One Engine Inoperative
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with maneuvering with one engine inoperative (simulated).

Task: A. Maneuvering with One Engine Inoperative
Description: Aerodynamics of multiengine flight with one engine inoperative (e.g., Vmc, asymmetrical thrust).

Task: A. Maneuvering with One Engine Inoperative
Description: Performance and limitations with one engine inoperative per the POH/AFM.

Task: A. Maneuvering with One Engine Inoperative
Description: Loss of control due to exceeding Vmc or improper technique with one engine inoperative.

Task: A. Maneuvering with One Engine Inoperative
Description: Collision hazards during low-altitude maneuvering with one engine inoperative.

Task: A. Maneuvering with One Engine Inoperative
Description: Recognize simulated engine failure and maintain control of the airplane above Vmc or Vsse, whichever is greater, ±5 knots.

Task: A. Maneuvering with One Engine Inoperative
Description: Perform maneuvers (e.g., turns, climbs) with one engine inoperative, maintaining altitude ±100 feet and heading ±10°.

Task: A. Maneuvering with One Engine Inoperative
Description: Complete the appropriate checklist for engine failure.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with demonstrating the minimum control speed with one engine inoperative (simulated).
Factors affecting Vmc (e.g., critical engine, weight, configuration).
Procedures for demonstrating Vmc per the POH/AFM.
Loss of control during a Vmc demonstration.
Establish the airplane in a configuration specified by the evaluator and reduce power on the critical engine until directional control can no longer be maintained with rudder alone.
Recover promptly by reducing power on the operating engine and increasing power as appropriate, maintaining altitude ±100 feet after recovery.

Task: C. Engine Failure During Takeoff Before Vmc (Simulated)
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with an engine failure during takeoff before Vmc (simulated).

Task: C. Engine Failure During Takeoff Before Vmc (Simulated)
Description: Procedures for engine failure during takeoff before Vmc per the POH/AFM.

Task: C. Engine Failure During Takeoff Before Vmc (Simulated)
Description: Delayed decision to abort takeoff after engine failure.

Task: C. Engine Failure During Takeoff Before Vmc (Simulated)
Description: Collision hazards during an aborted takeoff with one engine inoperative.

Task: C. Engine Failure During Takeoff Before Vmc (Simulated)
Description: Recognize simulated engine failure during takeoff roll and promptly abort the takeoff, maintaining directional control.

Task: C. Engine Failure During Takeoff Before Vmc (Simulated)
Description: Apply brakes and reduce power to stop in the shortest distance consistent with safety.
To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with an engine failure after lift-off (simulated).
Procedures for engine failure after lift-off per the POH/AFM.
Loss of control due to exceeding Vmc or improper technique after lift-off with one engine inoperative.
Collision hazards with obstacles or terrain during climb with one engine inoperative.
Recognize simulated engine failure after lift-off and maintain control above Vmc or Vsse, whichever is greater, ±5 knots.
Establish a climb at the recommended single-engine climb speed, maintaining heading ±10° and altitude ±100 feet after stabilization.
Complete the appropriate checklist for engine failure after lift-off.

Task: E. Approach and Landing with One Engine Inoperative (Simulated)
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with an approach and landing with one engine inoperative (simulated).

Task: E. Approach and Landing with One Engine Inoperative (Simulated)
Description: Procedures for approach and landing with one engine inoperative per the POH/AFM.

Task: E. Approach and Landing with One Engine Inoperative (Simulated)
Description: Unstabilized approach or loss of control during landing with one engine inoperative.

Task: E. Approach and Landing with One Engine Inoperative (Simulated)
Description: Collision hazards during approach and landing with one engine inoperative.

Task: E. Approach and Landing with One Engine Inoperative (Simulated)
Description: Recognize simulated engine failure and maintain control above Vmc or Vsse, whichever is greater, ±5 knots.

Task: E. Approach and Landing with One Engine Inoperative (Simulated)
Description: Establish a stabilized approach and land with one engine inoperative, touching down within 400 feet beyond a specified point, maintaining directional control.

Task: E. Approach and Landing with One Engine Inoperative (Simulated)
Description: Complete the appropriate checklist for engine failure during approach and landing.

Task: A. After Landing, Parking, and Securing
Description: To determine that the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with after-landing, parking, and securing procedures.

Task: A. After Landing, Parking, and Securing
Description: After-landing, parking, and securing procedures per the POH/AFM (e.g., shutdown, tie-down).

Task: A. After Landing, Parking, and Securing
Description: Airport ground operations (e.g., taxiway safety, parking areas).

Task: A. After Landing, Parking, and Securing
Description: Collision hazards with obstacles or other aircraft during ground operations after landing.

Task: A. After Landing, Parking, and Securing
Description: Improper securing of the airplane leading to damage from weather or unauthorized use.

Task: A. After Landing, Parking, and Securing
Description: Perform after-landing checklist and taxi to parking or ramp area, adhering to ATC or local procedures.

Task: A. After Landing, Parking, and Securing
Description: Park and secure the airplane using appropriate tie-downs or chocks, completing the shutdown checklist.
